cs671

Class HiLo

  • java.lang.Object
    • cs671.HiLo
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Guesser<Integer>

    public class HiLo
extends Object
implements Guesser<Integer>
    A simple guessing game. This game illustrates the Guesser interface. The user picks a number between a specified minimum and maximum and the guesser will discover the number by a repeated interaction of YES/NO questions. It proceeds by dichotomy, splitting the range of possible values in half with each question. After it's found, the number is returned as an instance of Integer.
    Version:
    2.3, 01/22/13
    Author:
    Michel Charpentier

      • HiLo

        public HiLo(int min,
    int max)
        Builds an instance of the engine for the given minimum and maximum.
        Parameters:
        min - the lower bound of the range
        max - the upper bound of the range
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the specified range is empty, i.e., min > max

    • Method Detail

      • initialize

        public String initialize()
        Initializes the guesser. This method must be called to start a new game.
        Specified by:
        initialize in interface Guesser<Integer>
        Returns:
        the string "Pick a number between X and Y", where X is the minimum and Y is the maximum, as specified when the instance was constructed

      • hasSolved

        public boolean hasSolved()
        Description copied from interface: Guesser
        Whether the problem has been solved. While this method returns false, users should continue to call methods makeQuestion, yes and no. Once it returns true, the method getSecret can safely be called.
        Specified by:
        hasSolved in interface Guesser<Integer>
        Returns:
        true iff the problem has been solved
        See Also:
        Guesser.makeQuestion(), Guesser.yes(), Guesser.no(), Guesser.getSecret()

      • progress

        public double progress()
        Indicates progress towards solving the problem. After initialization, the value returned is 0 (unless the problem is immediately solved, in which case it is 1). It always increases as the guessing process progresses. It is exactly 1 after the problem is solved.

        This implementation is logarithmic in the length of the remaining range, which is (roughly) linear in the number of remaining steps.

        Specified by:
        progress in interface Guesser<Integer>
        Returns:
        a value between 0 and 1 that is a measure of how much progress has been made towards solving the problem

      • getSecret

        public Integer getSecret()
        Description copied from interface: Guesser
        The answer to the problem. This method should be called after hasSolved returns true to retreive the solution to the problem.
        Specified by:
        getSecret in interface Guesser<Integer>
        Returns:
        the answer to the problem, if it is known
        See Also:
        Guesser.hasSolved()

      • makeQuestion

        public String makeQuestion()
        Generates a new question. The previous question must be answered (using yes or no) before a new question is generated.

        Note: for testing puposes, the question produced by this method must always be phrased as "Is your number larger than ... ?".

        Specified by:
        makeQuestion in interface Guesser<Integer>
        Returns:
        the question, as a string to be displayed to the user
        See Also:
        Guesser.initialize(), Guesser.hasSolved(), Guesser.yes(), Guesser.no()

      • yes

        public void yes()
        Description copied from interface: Guesser
        Used to reply YES to the previous question. Method makeQuestion must be called to generate a question before calling yes or no.
        Specified by:
        yes in interface Guesser<Integer>
        See Also:
